<<<api>>>: Java 8 Stream
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<DataSnapshot> it = dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
i = i + 1;
names.add(it.next().getValue(String.class));
}
<<<explanation>>>: You're creating a new dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator() in every iteration of your loop. Try to just use the value of the foreach inside the loop.

Regarding your second question, you can use the `head` and `tail` methods of the Java 8 Stream class to get the first and rest of the elements in the stream respectively.

Here's an example:

<<<api>>>: Java 8 Stream
<<<code>>>: IntStream primes = sieve(from(2));
primes.skip(1).forEach(System.out::println);

<<<explanation>>>: The `sieve` method returns an IntStream, which is a stream of integers. The `skip(1)` method skips the first element of the stream, and the `forEach` method prints the rest of the elements in the stream. The `System.out::println` is a method reference that prints the element to the console.
